title: Rugby World Cup final referee Jerome Garces will reward superior scrum
text:
Like most French referees, Jerome Garces is quite relaxed on the pitch.

He’s got a quiet confidence about himself and that’s really important on the big stage.

His interpretation around the breakdown can also be relaxed and that could work in favour of guys like Sam Underhill and Tom Curry.

Jerome Garces has been selected as the referee for this year's Rugby World Cup final

Garces upset Wales with his officiating in their semi-final defeat at the hands of South Africa

There might be a bit more time to hang around the base of the ruck and compete for the ball. Ultimately, it comes down to the flow of the game. The laws are the laws but each referee has their own interpretation.

England will concentrate on themselves first and foremost. Then they will want to be acutely aware of what South Africa are going to do but the third question is: ‘Who is the referee?’

The front row will look at scrummaging tendencies. Some referees are slower, some like to have it nice and steady, some want the ball played away quickly.

Garces is relaxed on the pitch, and will reward the superior scrum if there is dominance

With French referees, if you show a perceived dominance then they give you some reward.

That should be no different with Garces.

If you’re bigger, heavier and going forwards, that plants a seed in the ref’s head and the mauls and breakdowns start going your way.

What has been good at this World Cup is the lack of interference by the assistant referees.

A lot of decisions have been made on the run and that lets the game flow.
